DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Mass Uveal Melanoma Histologic Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of tissue in which a neoplasm that affects the uvea originated. Uveal melanoma is a representative example.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

Concepts.definition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 2/14/20 jk Upd RD to "Qualified"; CPTAC released AI. 1/2/20 jk Released per CPTAC SME (Linda) for PRAD Baseline CRF. 7/26/19 jk Updated OC term to Tumor Mass; used on multiple CPTAC CRFs.  6/26/19 jk created for CPTAC Baseline CRFs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm that affects the uvea.  Uveal melanoma is a representative example._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A blood vessel-containing membrane of the eye that lies between the retina and the sclera.

Concepts.definition: A blood vessel-containing membrane of the eye that lies between the retina and the sclera.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tissue located behind the iris and composed of muscle and epithelium. Its functions include the production of aqueous humor and changing the shape of the crystalline lens.

Concepts.definition: Tissue located behind the iris and composed of muscle and epithelium. Its functions include the production of aqueous humor and changing the shape of the crystalline lens.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The colored disc of the eye composed of connective tissue, epithelium, and endothelium. It separates the anterior chamber from the posterior chamber.

Concepts.definition: The colored disc of the eye composed of connective tissue, epithelium, and endothelium. It separates the anterior chamber from the posterior chamber.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A melanoma derived from melanocytes of the uveal tract.  It is the most common primary intraocular tumor in the United States and Western Europe.  Similar to melanoma of the skin, it is rare in Africa and Asia.  Diagnostic procedures include ophthalmoscopic exam, fluorescein angiography and ultrasound.  Treatment includes: surgical excision of the eye, iridocyclectomy and tumor resection.  Recent treatments also include radiotherapy or photo coagulation.  Classification of uveal melanomas recognizes four cell types within these tumors: epithelioid, intermediate, mixed cell, and spindle cell types.  The spindle cell type uveal melanomas are further sub-classified as spindle cell type A and spindle cell type B.:Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A melanoma derived from melanocytes of the uveal tract.  It is the most common primary intraocular tumor in the United States and Western Europe.  Similar to melanoma of the skin, it is rare in Africa and Asia.  Diagnostic procedures include ophthalmoscopic exam, fluorescein angiography and ultrasound.  Treatment includes: surgical excision of the eye, iridocyclectomy and tumor resection.  Recent treatments also include radiotherapy or photo coagulation.  Classification of uveal melanomas recognizes four cell types within these tumors: epithelioid, intermediate, mixed cell, and spindle cell types.  The spindle cell type uveal melanomas are further sub-classified as spindle cell type A and spindle cell type B.
Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
